[[World War I]] |mawards = [[Navy Cross (United States)|Navy Cross]] }} '''Adelbert Althouse''' (May 23, 1869 – May 17, 1954) was a [[United States Navy]] [[Captain (United States)#U.S. Navy, U.S. Coast Guard, U.S. Public Health Service, and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|Captain]] who served as the 27th and 29th [[Naval Governor of Guam]]. Prior to his Governorship, he served on ships in the Navy and participated in both the [[Spanish–American War]] and [[World War I]]. He earned the [[Navy Cross (United States)|Navy Cross]] for his actions commanding the [[USS Brooklyn (CA-3)|USS ''Brooklyn'']] and serving as Chief of Staff for the Commander and Chief of the [[United States Asiatic Fleet]] during the World War. As Governor, he focused on reforming the island's education system. He modeled a new system after that of co-educational [[California]], but also outlawed the speaking of the [[Chamorro language]] at schools in an effort to improve the [[English language]] skills of the local children. Most of his education reform took place in his first term. ==Life and legacy== Althouse was born in 1869 in [[Illinois]].{{cite book|title=Herrinshaw's National Library of American Biography|year=1909|publisher=[[American Publishers Association]]|location=[[Chicago]]|url=https://books.google.com/?id=urzTAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA107&dq=Adelbert+Althouse#v=onepage&q=Althouse&f=false|editor=[[Thomas William Herringshaw]]|accessdate=1 March 2011|page=107}} He died on May 17, 1954.{{cite news|title=Valor Awards for Adelbert Althouse |url=http://militarytimes.com/citations-medals-awards/recipient.php?recipientid=9090 |accessdate=1 March 2011 |newspaper=Military Times |agency=[[Gannett Government Media]] |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wrkvgAl4?url=http%3A%2F%2Fmilitarytimes.com%2Fcitations-medals-awards%2Frecipient.php%3Frecipientid%3D9090 |archivedate=1 March 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }} In 1930, the Navy named a Guamanian school, the Adelbert Althouse School, after him.{{cite web|title=Photo #: NH 987 |url=http://www.history.navy.mil/photos/images/h00001/h00987c.htm |work=Online Library of Selected Images |publisher=[[Naval History & Heritage Command]] |accessdate=3 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wudDEf9d?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.history.navy.mil%2Fphotos%2Fimages%2Fh00001%2Fh00987c.htm |archivedate=3 March 2011 |location=[[Washington, D.C.]] |date=9 November 2007 |deadurl=no |df= }} ==Naval career== Althouse entered the [[United States Naval Academy]] on May 21, 1887,{{cite web|title=US Navy Officers: 1798-1900 -- "A" |url=http://www.history.navy.mil/books/callahan/reg-usn-a.htm |work=Officers of the Continental U.S. Navy and Marine Corps, 1775-1900 |publisher=[[Naval History & Heritage Command]] |accessdate=3 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wudnfdS6?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.history.navy.mil%2Fbooks%2Fcallahan%2Freg-usn-a.htm |archivedate=3 March 2011 |location=[[Washington, D.C.]] |date=7 April 2006 |deadurl=yes |df= }} graduating in 1891. He was commissioned as an [[Ensign (rank)#United States|ensign]] on July 1, 1893. He achieved the rank of [[Lieutenant#Naval rank|lieutenant]] 1900. The same year, he served aboard the [[USS New Orleans (CL-22)|USS ''New Orleans'']].{{cite journal|title=Stations|journal=United States Congressional Serial Set|year=1900|issue=3982|url=https://books.google.com/?id=EI03AQAAIAAJ&pg=PA152&dq=Adelbert+Althouse#v=onepage&q=Adelbert%20Althouse&f=false|accessdate=3 March 2011|page=152}} As a lieutenant, he served as [[Watchstanding|watch]] and division officer aboard the [[USS Massachusetts (BB-2)|USS ''Massachusetts'']].{{cite news|title=Fire Directed at the Colon|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=SpI-AAAAIBAJ&sjid=XFoMAAAAIBAJ&pg=1552,1481207&dq=adelbert+althouse&hl=en|accessdate=3 March 2011|newspaper=[[Boston Evening Transcript]]|date=11 October 1901|agency=The Boston Transcript Company|location=[[Boston]]|page=1}} During this time, he participated in the [[Spanish–American War]].{{cite news|title=Commander of Indiana Was Not Notified by Schley That Cereva Was Coming Out-Try at Colon|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HBAbAAAAIBAJ&sjid=kEgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4018,5719572&dq=adelbert+althouse&hl=en|accessdate=3 March 2011|newspaper=[[Pittsburgh Press]]|date=11 October 1901|agency=[[E. W. Scripps Company]]|location=[[Pittsburgh]]|page=1}} In 1901, the navy assigned him to the [[USS Constellation (1854)|USS ''Constellation'']]. As a [[Lieutenant commander (United States)|lieutenant commander]], he served as [[Navigator|navigating officer]] aboard the [[USS Vermont (BB-20)|USS ''Vermont'']].{{cite book|title=The Navy|year=1908|publisher=Navy Publishing|url=https://books.google.com/?id=CHgDAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA31&dq=Adelbert+Althouse#v=onepage&q=Althouse&f=false|accessdate=3 March 2011|page=31}} During [[World War I]], Althouse served as [[Chief of Staff]] to the Commander in Chief of the [[United States Asiatic Fleet]] and commanded the [[USS Brooklyn (CA-3)|USS ''Brooklyn'']], for which he received the [[Navy Cross (United States)|Navy Cross]]. He retired with the rank of [[Captain (United States)#U.S. Navy, U.S. Coast Guard, U.S. Public Health Service, and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|Captain]].{{cite journal|last=Sorensen|first=Stan|title=Historical Notes|journal=Tapuitea|date=1 June 2010|volume=V|issue=22|url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:conEaYQj8LwJ:americansamoa.gov/tap2010/Tapuitea100601.pdf+Adelbert+Althouse+site:.gov&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESj4InykD-jieA1cVgrdoEiiJa874gGq-y_pBXFin2Zf4V9FJX131rZuw5qQDweiiHx8Xno8x3cVQ-IJTq5t2XUAT6GnubhU1hw0bbELHynCDqsX0zEqUQ-w2YGP4x1lsnEHpN8r&sig=AHIEtbSCQaq6gI6pGjVJap4K1HR49r8fJQ&pli=1|accessdate=3 March 2011|page=5|publisher=[[Government of American Samoa]]}} ==Governorship== Althouse served two terms as Naval Governor of Guam; his served his first term from February 7, 1922 to December 8, 1922.{{cite web|title=Naval Era Governors of Guam |url=http://guampedia.com/naval-era-governors-of-guam/ |work=Guampedia |publisher=[[University of Guam]] |accessdate=1 February 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5tqqTg3k2?url=http%3A%2F%2Fguampedia.com%2Fnaval-era-governors-of-guam%2F |archivedate=29 October 2010 |location=[[Guam]] |date=10 August 2010 |deadurl=no |df= }} During his first term, he made significant changes to the Guamanian education system. In an effort to promote the spread of [[English language|English]] among local children, he burned a large number of [[Chamorro language|Chamorro]]-English dictionaries and banned the use of Chamorro in the classroom and on playgrounds.{{cite web|last=Clement |first=Michael |title=Language Policies |url=http://guampedia.com/us-naval-era-language-policies/ |work=Guampedia |publisher=[[University of Guam]] |accessdate=1 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wrnpOyOA?url=http%3A%2F%2Fguampedia.com%2Fus-naval-era-language-policies%2F |archivedate=1 March 2011 |location=[[Guam]] |deadurl=no |df= }} Do to a shortage of classrooms, classrooms were made [[Mixed-sex education|co-educational]]. He based the new system on the educational system of [[California]] and demanded that teachers stick to a rigid syllabus.{{cite book|last=Rogers|first=Robert|title=Destiny's Landfall: A History of Guam|year=1995|publisher=[[University of Hawaii Press]]|location=[[Honolulu]]|isbn=0-8248-1678-1|url=https://books.google.com/?id=AEn9J3tXFS8C&pg=PA147&dq=Adelbert+Althouse#v=onepage&q=Adelbert%20Althouse&f=false|accessdate=3 March 2011|page=147}} His second term took place from December 14, 1922 to August 4, 1923. ==References== {{Research help|Mil}} {{reflist}} {{Governors of Guam}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Althouse, Adelbert}} [[Category:1869 births]] [[Category:1954 deaths]] [[Category:Governors of Guam]] [[Category:United States Naval Academy alumni]] [[Category:American military personnel of the Spanish–American War]] [[Category:American naval personnel of World War I]] [[Category:Recipients of the Navy Cross (United States)]] [[Category:Education reform]]
